Name: comment
Comment: all these stores are pretty junky and just promote the buy buy buy more more more mentality around clothes. They overwhelm buyers' senses to the point that when you walk in you want everything and nothing. Everything because it all looks kind of appealing in a very superficial way, and nothing because subconsciously you know you don't really need any of it. Some buyers will react by buying way more than they need and then feeling yucky about it, others will simply not be able to bear it and walk out as quickly as they walked in after a very brief glance around. These types of stores and the whole single-season pile-of-junk lots-of-shopping-time mentality they promote is the reason many people now shop online. Because you can zero in much more on what you actually need. People do NOT need a lot, they just need a few quality items that actually last. A lot of the clothes from these types of stores is ok until you wash it, and then it really changes somehow and is just never the same again. Europeans have a different mentality, at least used to, not so sure how it is now - they wear one outfit all week, changing maybe just the shirt and underwear, but it is quality stuff. The American economy is totally messed up. It's all about more more more, grow grow grow. Manipulate everyone into buying more junk, and then spending money on ways to get rid of it (what an irony!). It's not realistic. How can you have constant indefinite growth if the population isn't significantly increasing. It should be that a company just needs to maintain a steady revenue, fullfilling a particular and truly undeniable need. Stores like Gap confuse the human subconscious, because they are about want, not need. And people rarely truly know what they want and how much. Miserable miserable situation. Retail in general is a middle man, and so should be a very thin, minimal part of our economy.

Name: Jermaine Cornelius
Comment:
DRAB is the reason why I stopped shopping at GAP; the clothes there became very drab. Back in the mid to late 90's the GAP's clothes were stylish, colorful and very well made. I still have couple of sweaters and jackets that still look great today after all those years simply because they were very well made. But at some point during the mid 2000's their clothes became more and more drab and boring and meanwhile the prices stayed the same. I didn't mind the prices at all when the clothes were attractive. But I wasn't about to spend that kind of money on clothes that in my opinion looked lackluster + boring = DRAB. 

Since then it seems that more and more retailers are selling fast fashion which is pretty much the fast food of fashion because it is very cheaply made. A few years ago a H&M finally opened locally. I'd never been to one but I knew people who had shopped at one before and a lot of them raved about it. So I went there a few weeks after it's grand opening and it was a hot mess all up in there! It's common to see clothes tossed on floors in dressing rooms but clothes were strewn all over the entire store! It was as if a clothing bomb exploded in the place. Noticeably none of the employees seemed to care at all and neither did any of the crowd of customers. Of what was left hanging on racks I first noticed that the prices were extremely low. Secondly, the fact that the materials of the clothes looked and felt so poorly made explained why the prices were so cheap. I could tell right away that those clothes were only good for one or two wears, after that it wouldn't be any good. The quality was worse than Old Navy clothes because I think even Old Navy's clothes is more wearable after 1 or 2 wears. I thought to myself if that's what they want to buy so be it but I walked out of there and never went back.
